Award.AbstractNarration:
A central question in biology is to understand in detail how natural selection affects the evolution of a population. When one individual in a population acquires a beneficial mutation, that mutation may eventually spread to a large fraction of the population, or even the entire population. Modeling this phenomenon mathematically becomes particularly challenging when there can be many different beneficial mutations in the population at a time. This research project studies mathematical models of evolving populations that repeatedly acquire beneficial mutations. Because, in these models, populations are assumed to evolve in a random way, the theory of probability plays a central role in the analysis. The research aims to provide mathematical insight into important biological problems. Questions of interest include determining the rate at which the fitness of the population increases as a result of beneficial mutations, understanding the distribution of the fitness levels of individuals in the population at a given time, and understanding how to describe the genealogy of a sample from the population.

To model populations undergoing selection, the investigator will consider a stochastic process called branching Brownian motion. Each particle dies at a given rate, each particle moves independently according to one-dimensional Brownian motion, and particles occasionally split into two. Here particles represent individuals in a population, and the position of the particle along the real line corresponds to the individual's fitness. It will be assumed that the branching rate depends on the position of the particle, so that individuals with higher fitness have more offspring. It is conjectured that in the long-run, the empirical distribution of the positions of the particles is approximately Gaussian. A proof of this result would provide a mathematically rigorous formulation of the idea, well-established in the biology literature, that for certain populations undergoing selection, the distribution of the fitness levels of individuals in the population evolves like a Gaussian traveling wave. Because branching Brownian motion can be used to model populations experiencing either beneficial or deleterious mutations, this work could also shed light on a phenomenon known as Muller's ratchet, which refers to the decrease in the fitness of a population resulting from the accumulation of deleterious mutations. The investigator will also consider some population models that incorporate the effects of recombination, as well as a nested coalescent model that describes the genealogy of a collection of individuals sampled from multiple species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biologists are interested in understanding how populations evolve over time, and in particular how natural selection shapes the evolution of populations.  Because events such as births, deaths, and mutations are most naturally modeled as being random occurrences, the mathematical theory of probability plays a vital role in understanding the forces that govern the evolution of populations.  The goal of this project was to solve, using tools from probability theory, some challenging mathematical problems that arise when modeling evolving populations.

When studying populations, it is often important to understand the ancestral history of a sample of individuals taken from a population.  Mathematically, this is represented by a coalescent process, because when one follows ancestral lines backwards in time, the lineages will eventually merge as the individuals are traced back to a common ancestor.  Under a wide range of circumstances, this merging of lineages can be described by a process called Kingman's coalescent, in which only two lineages ever merge at a time.  However, in some circumstances, the ancestral structure of a population is best modeled by a so-called coalescent with multiple mergers, in which many lineages can merge at approximately the same time.  This can happen, for example, if one individual in the population acquires a beneficial mutation, which spreads rapidly to a substantial fraction of the population.  Then many ancestral lines will merge at approximately the same time because they all get traced back to the one individual that first acquired the beneficial mutation.  As part of this project, the PI, together with Fernando Cordero, Adrian Gonzalez Casanova, Maite Wilke-Berenguer, demonstrated that coalescents with multiple mergers can also potentially describe the ancestral structure of certain populations in which individuals periodically enter and leave a dormant state.  If one individual leaves the dormant state unusually early and is therefore able to produce a large number of offspring, many ancestral lines could be traced back to this individual, leading to a so-called multiple merger.

Biologists are also interested in understanding the evolutionary relationships among different species, a subject known as phylogenetics.  Instead of taking a sample of individuals from one species, one can sample individuals from different species and trace their ancestral lineages backwards in time.  The resulting process is known as a nested coalescent, or a multispecies coalescent.  The PI, together with Airam Blancas, Tim Rogers, and Arno Siri-Jegousse, established some new mathematical properties of nested coalescents as part of this project.

One way to model evolving populations undergoing natural selection is by using a mathematical process known as branching Brownian motion.  In this model, individuals are represented by particles, which move according to a process known as Brownian motion.  That is, they move haphazardly from left to right, much like a pollen grain suspended in a tube of water.  The location of the particle represents the fitness of the individual, with particles further to the right having higher fitness, so the motion of the particle corresponds to the change in fitness resulting from mutations.  Particles occasionally split into two particles to model births.  One way to model natural selection is to kill particles that move too far to the left, indicating that their fitness level drops below a threshold.  This process is known as branching Brownian motion with absorption because particles are killed (or absorbed) when they reach a certain level.  The PI, together with Pascal Maillard, established some new mathematical results about the behavior of branching Brownian motion with absorption when particles survive for an unusually long time.  These results sharpen earlier results due to Harry Kesten in 1978.  Another way to model natural selection is to allow particles that are further to the right to split into two particles more frequently because fitter individuals are more likely to have offspring.  The PI, together with Matt Roberts, undertook a detailed mathematical study of this model.  They showed that, after enough time has elapsed, the distribution of the fitness levels of individuals in the population will be approximately a normal distribution.  That is, if one were to plot the positions of the particles in a histogram, it would look like a bell-shaped curve. 

As part of this award, the PI supervised the research of five graduate students and one advanced undergraduate student.  The PI also presented the results at both traditional in-person conferences and online seminars and conferences.
